Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Reconciling Overprediction of Liquefaction-Induced Damage in Christchurch, New Zealand by Considering Spatial Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Widespread soil liquefaction during the events of the 2010-11 Canterbury Earthquake Sequence caused severe damage to the infrastructure and economy of Christchurch, New Zealand. Liquefaction occurs during earthquake shaking in sandy and silty soils, prevalent in the Christchurch region, and is characterized by strength loss resulting in ground deformations that can damage buildings, roads, pipelines, etc. In certain areas of Christchurch, conventional methods for assessing liquefaction damage potential tended to overpredict damages expected from these earthquakes; a common characteristic of these areas is the presence of thin liquefiable soil layers that are interlayered with non-liquefiable soils. Through collaboration with Dr. Misko Cubrinovski of the University of Canterbury in Christchurch, this project will utilize available field and laboratory data to perform numerical modeling of several sites with such interlayered soil deposits. Dr. Cubrinovski is an expert in geotechnical earthquake engineering and has been involved extensively in post-earthquake reconnaissance and research in Christchurch. The results of this work and the knowledge gained will provide a foundation for improved methods and guidance for evaluating liquefaction damage potential.

Previous work by the researcher has shown that in deposits of finely interbedded liquefiable and non-liquefiable soils, ground deformations can be limited by the non-liquefiable soil when pockets of liquefiable soil are laterally discontinuous. This is not considered in conventional methods, which are one-dimensional. The modeling to be performed will involve using a geostatistical approach along with available site data to build stochastic two-dimensional subsurface models of the sites and then performing dynamic analyses using ground motion records from the earthquakes. The intent is to see if inclusion of spatial variability in stratigraphy explains why liquefaction did not lead to damaging ground deformations for the shaking levels produced by the earthquakes. The issue of overprediction of liquefaction-induced damages has great significance, as the conventional methods for assessing damages are widely used in engineering practice around the world. As such, this work not only contributes to the ongoing recovery of Christchurch but also has an impact on assessment of liquefaction hazards in general.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The devastating Canterbury Earthquake Sequence (CES) of 2010-11 caused extensive damage in the city of Christchurch, New Zealand and nearby areas. Vast amount of data and information have been collected from geotechnical and geological site investigations, performance observations, and ground motion recordings. These have been instrumental in reconstruction efforts in Christchurch and can be used to advance civil earthquake engineering practice by evaluating engineering procedures against them.

    A large portion of the damage in Christchurch was due to the occurrence of soil liquefaction. Liquefaction occurs during earthquake shaking in saturated sandy and silty soils, prevalent in the Christchurch region. Shaking causes soil particles to rearrange, resulting in increased water pressure and strength loss that can cause ground deformations that damage buildings, roads, pipelines, etc. In certain areas of Christchurch, conventional analysis methods for assessing liquefaction damage potential tended to overpredict damages expected from these earthquakes; a common characteristic of these areas is the presence of thin layers of liquefiable soils that are interbedded with non-liquefiable soils.

    The principal investigator (PI) of this project spent two months in Christchurch at the University of Canterbury investigating sites with interbedded liquefiable and non-liquefiable soils that experienced less damage than expected based on conventional analysis methods. In collaboration with other researchers in New Zealand from academia and engineering practice, eleven sites that experienced less damage than predicted were identified for investigation. Geotechnical subsurface data from these sites were collected from the online New Zealand Geotechnical Database (NZGD) and processed. One or more cross sections were selected from each site and the data along these cross sections were used to perform conventional liquefaction analyses. Software tools were developed to accomplish these tasks. Examination of the cross sections along with geological maps identified two sites that had interbedded liquefiable and non-liquefiable soils that were interesting for further analysis. Geostatistical simulation was performed for one of these sites to represent the interbedded and spatially variable stratigraphy.

    Outcomes of this project were scientific, practical, and educational. The project produced a collection of detailed notes and data on several liquefaction sites in Christchurch that may be used for further study by the PI and/or other researchers from his cohort. The software tools developed for data collection, processing, and analysis may also be useful for future studies. The project demonstrated that geostatistical analysis and simulation can be accomplished using geotechnical data and can be useful for geotechnical studies of sites with spatially variable stratigraphy. The PI gained experience examining geotechnical and geological information and understanding its implications on liquefaction behavior. Ideas were exchanged and connections were made through the collaborations with researchers in New Zealand. The PI learned about modern and historical culture of New Zealand by attending an EAPSI program orientation hosted by the Royal Society of New Zealand and by living, working, and travelling in the country.

    Funding support for this project was provided by the National Science Foundation and the Royal Society of New Zealand.


Last Modified: 04/07/2017
Modified by: Sean K Munter

  • Site 7 with ground surface damage observations from Feb. 2011 earthquake and locations of CPTs (red markers). Two cross sections (white lines) intersecting the stream channel (blue line) were examined.

    Sean K Munter
    Site 7 damage observations and field tests

    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)

    Sloping ground along stream channel at Site 7

    CPT Data: Canterbury Geotechnical Database; Plotting: Matplotlib
    Copyrighted
    Sean K Munter
    Geotechnical data along cross section at Site 7
  • 3-dimensional view of the CPT tests at Site 7, with soils classified as loose sand-like soils, dense sand-like soils, or clay-like.
    Plotting: Matplotlib
    Copyrighted
    Sean K Munter
    3-D view of data at Site 7
  • Geostatistical simulation of soil category locations at Site 7 accomplished with Transition probability geostatistical software (T-PROGS). The simulation is conditioned on known data from the CPTs.
    Simulation: T-PROGS (Carle 1999)
    Copyrighted
    Sean K Munter
    3-D geostatistical simulation of Site 7
  • Investigation sites (yellow pin markers) shown along with selected cross sections and locations of geotechnical cone penetration tests (CPTs) (red markers) along the cross sections.
    Map imagery: Google, Terra Metrics, Digital Globe; Test locations: New Zealand Geotechnical Database
    Sean K Munter
    Investigation sites
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The devastating Canterbury Earthquake Sequence (CES) of 2010-11 caused extensive damage in the city of Christchurch, New Zealand and nearby areas. Vast amount of data and information have been collected from geotechnical and geological site investigations, performance observations, and ground motion recordings. These have been instrumental in reconstruction efforts in Christchurch and can be used to advance civil earthquake engineering practice by evaluating engineering procedures against them. A large portion of the damage in Christchurch was due to the occurrence of soil liquefaction. Liquefaction occurs during earthquake shaking in saturated sandy and silty soils, prevalent in the Christchurch region. Shaking causes soil particles to rearrange, resulting in increased water pressure and strength loss that can cause ground deformations that damage buildings, roads, pipelines, etc. In certain areas of Christchurch, conventional analysis methods for assessing liquefaction damage potential tended to overpredict damages expected from these earthquakes; a common characteristic of these areas is the presence of thin layers of liquefiable soils that are interbedded with non-liquefiable soils. The principal investigator (PI) of this project spent two months in Christchurch at the University of Canterbury investigating sites with interbedded liquefiable and non-liquefiable soils that experienced less damage than expected based on conventional analysis methods. In collaboration with other researchers in New Zealand from academia and engineering practice, eleven sites that experienced less damage than predicted were identified for investigation. One or more cross sections were selected from each site and the data along these cross sections were used to perform conventional liquefaction analyses. Examination of the cross sections along with geological maps identified two sites that had interbedded liquefiable and non-liquefiable soils that were interesting for further analysis. Geostatistical simulation was performed for one of these sites to represent the interbedded and spatially variable stratigraphy. Outcomes of this project were scientific, practical, and educational. The project produced a collection of detailed notes and data on several liquefaction sites in Christchurch that may be used for further study by the PI and/or other researchers from his cohort. The software tools developed for data collection, processing, and analysis may also be useful for future studies. The project demonstrated that geostatistical analysis and simulation can be accomplished using geotechnical data and can be useful for geotechnical studies of sites with spatially variable stratigraphy. The PI gained experience examining geotechnical and geological information and understanding its implications on liquefaction behavior. Ideas were exchanged and connections were made through the collaborations with researchers in New Zealand. The PI learned about modern and historical culture of New Zealand by attending an EAPSI program orientation hosted by the Royal Society of New Zealand and by living, working, and travelling in the country. Funding support for this project was provided by the National Science Foundation and the Royal Society of New Zealand. Last Modified: 04/07/2017 Submitted by: Sean K Munter
